Award.AwardTitle: Drawing on Concepts in Finance for Construction Schedule Performance Measurement

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to investigate how performance can be made comparable across a wide range of construction project sizes and types. Performance is at the core of all managerial functions of decision makers; planning how projects should progress, controlling how they perform, and, if necessary, deploying remedies to bring lagging ones back on track. Yet despite, or perhaps because of the size of the construction industry as being a major contributor to the overall economy, its enormous number of projects, and their variety, no single measure has emerged that provides such a desired snapshot assessment. Existing attempts, which simply provide the percentage of total work or cite the 'value' that a schedule or budget has achieved, conceptually suffer from the problem that they converge to 'one' (work completed) or 'zero' (work remaining) at the project end, so that the mere fact that it was eventually finished makes a project appear successful and any problems that occurred are forgotten. This gives an overly optimistic, incomplete, and non-predictive view. This research will therefore glean inspiration from finance, where notwithstanding the diverse nature of publicly traded companies, investors have long quantified stock performance with universal metrics. Specifically, the proven concept of 'beta', which expresses volatility of a stock compared to its market, will be explored for adaptation as a schedule performance metric. If successful, this research will enhance transparency of construction projects in light of still-too-common schedule delays and productivity shortfalls, enable identification and targeted improvements of underperforming activities, projects, or firms, and support the competitiveness of participants within the U.S. construction economy. Educational outreach at the after-school ACE mentor program, which serves many minority high school students, will build a group activity that playfully embodies insights from the research.

The research methodology is a process of knowledge transfer, from concept extraction via adaptation to verification and validation steps. The research team will collate analogies by mapping and matching them in a concept matrix with their equivalents of project management. Criteria for inclusion and any adjustment, assumption, or limitation will be proximity in meaning and predictiveness toward creating a functioning model that can reflect schedule performance. Validating the new approach will employ statistical analysis of artificial and real-world schedules from corporate partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Time is considered a fundamental dimension of construction project management, alongside safety, quality, and cost. Projects are coordinated by schedules from mobilization to handover. They show work items (activities) with their respective sequential dependency. On-time delivery is essential to owners, who expect to use their new facility punctually, and contractors, who want to avoid late fees and hope to earn an early completion bonus. The schedule tracks how well a project and its participants are doing. One may thus assume that time performance can be measured and compared, so that contractors can advertise it and owners can select based upon it. But surprisingly, no metric has existed before this research. Due to ubiquitous delays, the National Research Council called for “improved efficiency and competitiveness” within the construction industry due to the proverbial ‘what cannot be measured cannot be controlled’.

 

While the existing Earned Value method compares actual to planned work in construction schedules, it does so only as a monetary ratio, not time units. Worse, its index defaults to 100% (work complete) at the project finish; even a terribly delayed project has an apparently perfect score, simply for being done. Worst, the ratio cannot be generalized beyond the current project; forecasting to future ones is impossible. Yet successful metrics exist in other areas: Safety management uses the Experience Modification Rate to express if a firm has more or less accidents than the industry average, which in turn determines its insurance premiums, a powerful incentive. Inspiration is also gained from finance, whose daily published ‘beta’ tracks the performance of publicly traded firms relative to the entire stock market, despite such companies having vastly different products or services.

 

Intellectual Merit: This research has therefore investigated how such a time performance metric can be established, how it behaves under various circumstances, and how it can be effectively disseminated. Its methodology aggregates knowledge from the aforementioned areas via concept extraction and matching. Close analogies are identified between stocks within their market and contractors within construction. Just as daily trading values are input for calculating the stock beta, so completed projects by contractors can be used to calculate their schedule beta. And like the unitless beta can be aggregated from individual companies to sectors or industries, so can different levels in construction be tracked, starting at individual subcontractors, whom general contractors hire to perform specialized work.

 

Schedule beta is newly defined as covariance of activity and project deviations divided by the variance of project deviation, where each deviation is as-built minus as-scheduled duration. Scenarios with realistic planned and actual activity durations of multiple subcontractors on several projects have been simulated to establish guidelines: Multiple projects are required as data, because the beta definition performs a mathematical comparison. The similarity of its formula to correlation provides an analogy for interpreting results without implying causation. Accuracy increases with larger datasets.

 

Real-world data have been collected from the industry partner and carefully collated for analysis. They comprise some 190 subcontractors with 8000 activities on 7 mixed-use projects. Several challenges have been identified and solved: Activity labels were inconsistent or were even reused in the dataset, so that a correction procedure of checking activity descriptions had to be developed. The schedules grew with monthly schedule updates, because activities were added or subdivided as the initial baseline schedule was refined. The final dataset comprises the first and last instances of dates as planned and actual starts and finishes, from which durations and then deviations were calculated. Change orders by the owner simply yield adjusted planned dates.

 

Schedule structure is considered by calculating the complexity of network schedules of different sizes. They range from zero (parallel) to one (sequential), where realistic projects typically feature a network structure with medium complexity. Local delays can have a ripple effect on successor activities. It is extracted by combining the correlation of activity and project duration with how reachable activities are within a network and how often they are critical (have zero flexibility) in simulations. This cruciality newly expresses the potential percent contribution of an individual subcontractor activity to a unit delay of the project. Project managers can thus focus on crucial activities, especially merges, and crucial paths. Parallel structures are more resilient to delays, because concurrent activities remain unaffected.

 

Broader Impacts: To widely share results with construction and even other industries, a concept for an ASTM standard has been submitted for review. Educational outreach has involved university and minority high school students, for whom a performance card game has been created. Separate funding from the Charles Pankow Foundation has supported validating the new theory and is gratefully acknowledged. It is hoped that schedule beta ultimately becomes a living benchmark that enables project participants to be positively incentivized to measure and publish their time performance in fulfillment of the National Research Council’s call for action.
